skills.name: Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots
Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots

explanations.A: Substituting the values in: ab = 4 ✕ 3 = 12 and a ＋ b = 4 ＋ 3 = 7. And we know that 12 > 7 so the star needs to be replaced by '>'.
explanations.B: What does ab mean? How do we calculate it if a = 4 and b = 3? What is a + b equal to? Are they the same or is one of these expressions bigger than the other?
explanations.C: What does ab mean? How do we calculate it if a = 4 and b = 3? What is a + b equal to? Are they the same or is one of these expressions bigger than the other?
explanations.D: What does ab mean? How do we calculate it if a = 4 and b = 3? What is a + b equal to? Are they the same or is one of these expressions bigger than the other?

explanations.A: What does ab mean? How do we calculate it if a = 1 and b = 4? What is a + b equal to? Are they the same or is one of these expressions bigger than the other?
explanations.B: Substituting the values in: ab = 1 ✕ 4 = 4 and a ＋ b = 1 ＋ 4 = 5. We know that 4 < 5 so the star needs to be replaced by '<'.
explanations.C: What does ab mean? How do we calculate it if a = 1 and b = 4? What is a + b equal to? Are they the same or is one of these expressions bigger than the other?
explanations.D: What does ab mean? How do we calculate it if a = 1 and b = 4? What is a + b equal to? Are they the same or is one of these expressions bigger than the other?

explanations.A: Substituting the values in: a − b = 4 − 3 = 1 and b − a = 3 − 4 = −1. We know that 1 > −1, meaning Answer A is correct.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why a - b is NOT less than b - a. If it's not less than, which symbol should replace the star?
explanations.C: Be careful. Subtraction does not work the same as addition. Switching the order of the numbers will change the answer. Try substituting in the values for a and b to see which symbol should replace the star.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 3 and 4 to see if these expressions are equal or if one is bigger than the other.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why a - b is NOT more than b - a. If it's not more than, which symbol should replace the star?
explanations.B: Substituting the values in: a − b = 1 − 4 = −3 and b − a = 4 − 1 = 3. We know that −3 < 3, meaning Answer B is correct.
explanations.C: Be careful. Subtraction does not work the same as addition. Switching the order of the numbers will change the answer. Try substituting in the values for a and b to see which symbol should replace the star.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 1 and 4 to see if these expressions are equal or if one is bigger than the other.

explanations.A: Substituting the values in: a/b = 4/3 = 1⅓ and b/a = ¾. We know that 1⅓ > ¾, meaning Answer A is correct.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why a/b is NOT less than b/a. Remember common denominators can help us compare fractions.
explanations.C: Not quite. Two fractions are equivalent if you can multiply (or divide) the numerator and denominator, of one of the fractions, by the same number to get the other fraction. This is not the case here. Try substituting in the values for a and b and then use equivalent fractions to give them common denominators so that you can compare them.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 3 and 4, and then find a common denominator, to see if these fractions are equal or if one is bigger than the other.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why 4a/b is NOT more than b/a. Remembering that the fraction line means divide will help you compare these fractions.
explanations.B: Substituting the values in: (4a)/b = (4 ✕ 1)/4 = 4/4 = 1 and b/a = 4/1 = 4. We know that 1 < 4, meaning Answer B is correct.
explanations.C: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why 4a/b is NOT equal to b/a. Remembering that the fraction line means divide will help you compare these fractions.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 1 and 4, and then use the fact that the fraction line means divide to compare these fractions.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why aᵇ is NOT more than bᵃ. Remember 4³ = 4 x 4 x 4.
explanations.B: Substituting the values in: aᵇ = 4³ = 4 ✕ 4 ✕ 4 = 64 and bᵃ = 3⁴ = 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 = 81. We know that 64 < 81, meaning Answer B is correct.
explanations.C: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why aᵇ is NOT equal to bᵃ. Remember 4³ = 4 x 4 x 4.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 3 and 4 to see what symbol should replace the star. Remember 4³ = 4 x 4 x 4.

explanations.A: Substituting the values in: (−a)ᵇ = (−1)⁴ = −1 ✕ −1 ✕ −1 ✕ −1 = ＋1 and −bᵃ = −4¹ = −4. We know that ＋1 > −4, meaning Answer A is correct.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why (-a)ᵇ is NOT less than -bᵃ. Remember (-1)⁴ = -1 x -1 x -1 x -1.
explanations.C: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why (-a)ᵇ is NOT equal to -bᵃ. Remember (-1)⁴ = -1 x -1 x -1 x -1.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 1 and 4 to see what symbol should replace the star. Remember (-1)⁴ = -1 x -1 x -1 x -1.

explanations.A: We can substitute for a and b in the expression. 3a means '3 multiplied by a' so 3a – b becomes 3 x 6 – 5. We do 3 x 6 = 18 first, then subtract 5 to get an answer of 13.
explanations.B: I think you have written '3a' as 36. When we have a number in front of a letter in algebra, it tells us how many lots of the letter we have. In other words, '3a' means 3 multiplied by a.
explanations.C: I think you might have added b, instead of subtracting. Work out 3a first, then remember to subtract b.
explanations.D: I think you might have mixed up the letters and worked out 3b – a instead. It's a good idea to write out the expression and then re-write it with the correct numbers substituted for a and b before you start calculating. So I would write 3a - b first, then 3 x 6 – 5.

explanations.A: I think you have written '3a' as 38. When we have a number in front of a letter in algebra, it tells us how many lots of the letter we have. In other words, '3a' means 3 multiplied by a.
explanations.B: I think you might have added b, instead of subtracting. Work out 3a first, then remember to subtract b.
explanations.C: We can substitute for a and b in the expression. 3a means '3 multiplied by a' so 3a – b becomes 3 x 8 – 3. We do 3 x 8 = 24 first, then subtract 3 to get an answer of 21.
explanations.D: I think you might have mixed up the letters and worked out 3b – a instead. It's a good idea to write out the expression and then re-write it with the correct numbers substituted for a and b before you start calculating. So I would write 3a - b first, then 3 x 6 – 5.
